urn:contentItem:59PV-J6X1-DXH2-64YM-00000-00Sebelius in Congress Today; Clamor for Sebelius to be Fired2013-10-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:02ZLexisNexisTHE WILLIS REPORT6:00 PM ESTDoug Holtz-Eakin, Bill Johnson, John Barrasso, Avik Roy, Tom Miller, Theresa PaytonNEWSFinancial103001cb.222Sebelius in Congress Today; Clamor for Sebelius to be FiredGerri Willis, Rich Edson

GERRI WILLIS, FBN HOST: Hello, everybody. I'm Gerri Willis.

Tonight on a special edition of THE WILLIS REPORT, live from Washington, D.C., hey it's sorry but nothing is changing. That's the takeaway from Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius testifying before the House Energy and Commerce Committee on the Obamacare website mess today. She's apologizing but not rolling back on deadlines. Americans will still have to pay fines if they don't play along with the White House's tune.

Here to weigh in, Doug Holtz-Eakin, president of the American Action Form and Republican congressman Bill Johnson of Ohio who is at the hearing today. Doug, I'm going to start with you. We got an apology.

DOUG HOLTZ-EAKIN, AMERICAN ACTION FORUM PRESIDENT: Yes.

WILLIS: Obviously - were you satisfied with what you heard?

HOLTZ-EAKIN: Well, I thought the secretary did a good job, quite frankly. She had the right demeanor. I thought the apology rang true. And she did her job in that she answered the question she wanted to answer and she didn't answer the ones that they did not want her to talk about.

WILLIS: It was a lot that didn't get answered today. We will hit on some of that. But you know, this got testy testing many, many times. And Sebelius telling Marsha Blackburn the congresswoman to hold her accountable. Even that was testy. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R), TENNESSEE: Who is in charge, madam secretary?

KATHLEEN SEBELIUS, HHS SECRETARY: The person now in charge as an integrator is QSSI, one of our -

BLACKBURN: Who was in charge?

SEBELIUS: -- was in charge -

BLACKBURN: AT that team who is the individual -

SEBELIUS: Michele Snyder.

BLACKBURN: Michele Snyder is the one responsible for this debacle.

SEBELIUS: Well, excuse me, congresswoman, Michele Snyder is not responsible for the debacle, hold me accountable for the debacle. I'm responsible.

BLACKBURN: OK.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: I'm responsible. You just heard that from the secretary of Health and Human Services.

Congressman, if she's accountable, why does she still have the job?

REP. BILL JOHNSON (R), OHIO: Well, that's a good question. You know, Kathleen Sebelius serves at the pleasure of the president, as does the lady that she said was in charge. If that's the kind of performance that they are willing to tolerate, I can tell you my experience as a program manager, I would not have had a job if I had performed like this.

WILLIS: You know, I think in the private sector nobody understands what's going on. I tell you in New York we are all mystified. But here in Washington, different rules apply. Here is my big question. And my take away from the whole thing today. She seemed to be saying, "We are sorry. We are sorry. We really didn't mean it. We apologize," but at the same time, you are getting no brakes. We might have screwed up but you're getting no delay in deadlines, you're still going to have to pay penalties. It's all on you. Doug.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: That's exactly right. Remember, the president said, "This is more than a website," and they believe that deeply. They want the policies, they want the whole agenda, and they believe that they can get people to the polls one way or another. They've done it before. They think about it like a political campaign and they're going to try to get in there one way or another.

WILLIS: Congressman, you're an expert in IT. You've spent part of your career and IT, certainly in school in IT, you've studied it. Is Kathleen Sebelius the right person to run what is a massive e-commerce website?

JOHNSON: Well, apparently not because many, many mistakes were made. You know, I've looked through the contracts. I've seen the testing that was required to be performed under that contract. We know now that integration testing didn't even begin until two weeks prior to going live. They were supposed to do a full suite of testing, part of a pre-operational readiness review back in the fourth quarter of 2012 and then a final review with test results, test analysis, and all of that in the first quarter of 2013. And I can't find anyone there that will tell me whether that has occurred or not.

WILLIS: What grade do you give them? (INAUDIBLE) somebody who knows how well it done.

JOHNSON: Well, it's failed. It is absolutely an F. That's the grade they give.

WILLIS: All right. I want you to hear some more - this is from Congressman Mike Rogers questioning Sebelius on this very issue.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. MIKE ROGERS: You accepted a risk on behalf of every user of this computer that put their personal financial information at risk because you did not even have the most basic end-to-end test for security of the system. Amazon would never do this. Pro Flowers would never do this. Kayak would never do this.

I will commit today secretary to shut down the system and do an end to end security test so that these Americans -

SEBELIUS: No, sir.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: All right. So if you heard the tail end of that, what she said is no. We are not shutting it down. We're not shutting it down for an end to end test even though that that may be the only way to find out what is wrong. Doug.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: This was a bull's-eye. This is a deep concern to the American public. The privacy of their personal information is paramounts. They played politics with this schedule. They played politics with the policy. But you can't play politics with people's privacy. That is going to hurt and then you can worry about it.

WILLIS: Or your health care, in my view. I think that is why people are so upset. This policy is right up in people's grill. It's about how much health care you get, what you're going to pay for it, what the quality of your life is really going to be like.

Congressman, to you. I was amused to hear that the federal chief information officer today said, "What we have been through is a teachable moment." What do you make of that?

JOHNSON: A teachable moment?

WILLIS: A teachable moment.

JOHNSON: I would like to have him in my class because I have a few things that I would like to teach. You just don't get this far into an implementation with these many problems and think that you're going to be able to fix it. They may create a perception that it is being fixed, but I submit that it is going to cost millions, if not hundreds of millions of dollars more to repair and replace this system than to simply fix it. It is badly, badly broken.

WILLIS: We are still waiting on those numbers. We don't really know those numbers, how much it costs, how much of the taxpayer money were sunk into this.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: Right. The transparency is terrible. For an administration that publicly prides itself on transparency, you can't find out anything in this process. I think there are too big lessons that are going to play in the debate for a long time.

There is a generation of Americans who believed the president when he said that government solves problems. The government is an active force in your life. But they didn't understand government fails. And fails a lot. This is a massive failure. They're learning that lesson. They also will learn that this - the private sector succeeds because there is a financial incentive to make trades, make transactions. Why does the New York Stock Exchange work? That exchange works for a reason. So does the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, so does Amazon, so does Ebay. That is a lesson as well.

JOHNSON: Gerri, the biggest concern that I've got right now is what he said. You know, it's easy to spend somebody else's money when it's not coming out of your pocket. I mean the American taxpayers have already paid for this system one time. And it was badly flawed.

Now they're being asked to pay for it again because this new systems integrator, that was supposed to be independent, QSSI, that was part of the development team and part of the independent (INAUDIBLE).

WILLIS: In the first place.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: In the first place.

JOHNSON: Is now going to be paid more to try and rescue this system. I want to know how they're going to recover the money and pay for this thing without taking (INAUDIBLE).

WILLIS: One of the scariest words in the English language. I'm from the government (INAUDIBLE). Guys, thanks for helping me out tonight. You did a great job. Thanks, congressman.

Jonathan, Doug will be with us after the break.

But first we want to know what you think. Here is our question tonight - do you buy Sebelius' apology? Log on to gerriwillis.com. Vote on the right hand side of the screen. I will show the results at the end of tonight's show. We got more and more to come. From Washington D.C., this hour, including calls for Kathleen Sebelius to throw in the towel.

And next, more on the lies and broken promises of this law, especially the one we got to keep your insurance plan. Remember that. Senator John Barrasso is here after the break. Stay with us.

WILLIS: Time and time again the president campaigning on this promise to the American people in his push for Obamacare.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If you like your doctor you will be able to keep her doctor. Period. If you like your health care plan, you will be able to keep your health care plan. Period.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: A promise broken hundreds of thousands, if not millions of times over as more insurance cancellations keep people - keep these pouring into the mailbox.

We're live in D.C. bringing you the very latest on the Obamacare fiasco. Back with me now, Doug Holtz-Eakin from the American Action Forum. And joining us to is Republican Senator John Barrasso of Wyoming.

Senator, I will start with you. You know, we have been talking about this broken promise. Essentially Democrats have said, you can't complain about the law. It's the law of the land. But if it was sold on bad information, what does that mean?

SEN. JOHN BARRASSO (R), TENNESSEE: Well, I think the president intentionally had these lines designed to deceive the American people. So they could force through of party-line vote a health care law that I think is bad for patients as well as doctors and nurses who take care of them as well as the taxpayers this - the problems with the website are only the tip of the iceberg. The law itself is fatally flawed in terms of keeping your doctor, in terms of all of these cancellations of policies. (INAUDIBLE).

WILLIS: I'm going to show some numbers on that right now because we have been running a tally on the cancellations. I've got something like - 1.7 million. If you add up all these numbers from all over the country, we're seeing hundreds of thousands of people getting cancellations every day.

And in the testimony today, Sebelius was saying those aren't cancellations. If they're not cancellations , what are they?

HOLTZ-EAKIN: They are cancellations, and there are more to come. Because there are more and more of these so-called grandfather plans where they will have to make enough changes to comply with the law that they'll be canceled. They're no longer legal for sale and that's that and it's because the law (INAUDIBLE) on that front.

BARRASSO: And the regulations that they wrote afterwards because you have a tower of regulations that's going to be tall. They've really got very restrictive in the regulations when the president said "If you like your insurance, you can keep your insurance." It really only if the White House likes your insurance.

WILLIS: That's right.

BARRASSO: You can keep your insurance. And if the White House doesn't like your insurance you can keep it.

WILLIS: Essential health benefits. I want you to hear from Cory Gardner. He's a congressman who got up in today's hearing and said "Here's my cancellation notice. I just got it." Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. CORY GARDNER (R), COLORADO: This is the letter that my family got canceling our insurance. We chose to have our just have our own private policy back in Colorado so we could be in the same boat as every one of my constituents, and yet my insurance policy has been canceled. The White House website says if you like your health plan you can keep it. Did I hear it wrong?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: So you hear the congressman say he has lost his health insurance. He's very upset. He went on to say to Kathleen Sebelius, "I think you should be enrolled in Obamacare. Why aren't you enrolled in Obamacare?" What did you make of that exchange?

BARRASSO: Well, I think that every employee in the White House ought to be involved and enrolled in the Obama health care law and (INAUDIBLE) to buy insurance on the exchanges. None of them - they all have exemptions from this health care law. I think they all should be involved. But he is right, and it is not just people losing their coverage but then they have to go and buy insurance, they're getting hit with sticker shock, Gerri, because they are seeing it's turning out to be a lot more expensive.

Remember, the president promised easier to use than Amazon, the website, cheaper than your cellphone bill, and you can keep your doctor. And the American people feel deceived by the lines of the president.

WILLIS: Exactly.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: And that is really important. Because the way they tried to keep prices down and there's a lot of sticker shock already, is to have tight networks. That means you probably won't get to see your doctor or go to the usual hospital.

WILLIS: I think we are all headed for RNs, I think at the end of the day. I want you to hear something from Congressman Lee Terry. Because another issue for me has been when are we going to get details, when are we going to know, understand how many people are being enrolled? It's an open question. Here is what he had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. LEE TERRY (R), NEBRASKA: That should be a pretty reliable number.

SEBELIUS: The system is not functioning. So we are not getting that reliable data.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: So the secretary says essentially we don't know because we are not getting reliable data. Doug.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: I find this the least believable in a long list of things that are believable.

WILLIS: That's not true.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: Pick up the phone. Insurance companies in America know who they have signed up. If they have completed a contract with somebody, it has gone down to the billed out for premiums and they're going to know. Ask the insurers. How many have you signed up. How many have you signed up? Add (INAUDIBLE).

WILLIS: I don't think the insurers have good information either.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: They may not have the right information about who they signed up but they're going to know how many people have made it through the process. They have to.

BARRASSO: And our insurance commissioner in the state of Wyoming, he has tried to log on to the website every day since October 1st, has not gotten through as of this past week. Lisa Markowsky, the senator from Alaska told a number of us today that they made the calls. There are three people in the state of Alaska who have been able to sign up.

WILLIS: Let me tell you, one thing that was almost missed in the coverage today because we weren't in the room. We're watching it on TV. They have a video up of the website. It was not available. You couldn't sign on during that very congressional hearing that is investigating why this website is not up. This is like prime time for the administration. If you are able to get this website to work, it would be during this congressional hearing. It did not happen.

BARRASSO: And if you're ever going to try to convince young healthy individuals to sign up, they are losing this (INAUDIBLE).

(CROSSTALK)

BARRASSO: These are the people that have to sign up for the financing of the whole program to work. They're depending on 2.7 million young people to pay more for more insurance than they need to pay for older, sicker people.

WILLIS: Right.

BARRASSO: And that is what this whole thing is built upon.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: They touted some numbers. You heard the president, for example, say more than 60,000 people.

WILLIS: Right.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: Those are all Medicaid recipients. Those are not people - the Oregon exchange has not yet opened. And so they are also not being clear about who is in what category. It will have a very, very, very (INAUDIBLE) rollout.

WILLIS: If you have to guess the proportion of people who are signing up now, who are actually on Medicaid rather than Obamacare, what would it be?

HOLTZ-EAKIN: I guess 90 percent.

WILLIS: We're going to have to leave it there. Senator, Doug, thanks for being with us. Great job. Fascinating conversation. Really appreciate your time.

HOLTZ-EAKIN: Thank you.

WILLIS: And later in the show, hear what President Obama had to say following his secretary's testimony.

Next, despite getting some praise for performance today many in Congress are calling for Sebelius to be fired, and one of those senators, Lamar Alexander, joins me next. Stay with us.

WILLIS: The top Republican on the Senate's health panel calling for Kathleen Sebelius to quit. His reaction to her testimony, next.

WILLIS: With the unsuccessful rollout of the Obamacare website, many lawmakers have been calling for Health and Human Services secretary Kathleen Sebelius to resign, adding to that, chorus of calls is the ranking member on the Health Education, Labor and Pensions Committee, Senator Lamar Alexander of Tennessee. Earlier today, I spoke with him and asked him if he was satisfied with what he heard today.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SEN. LAMAR ALEXANDER (R), TENNESSEE: I'm not satisfied. She should step down. I mean, this is the private sector, that kind of performance would not be tolerated. And she should step down and somebody else should take charge.

WILLIS: Well, she said she was sorry. She said she regretted it. She says she's working on all the problems. Why isn't that good enough?

ALEXANDER: Well, it's not good enough. You know, Admiral Rickover created our nuclear navy and told the captains of the submarines, "Look, you are in charge of the reactor, too. There is ever a problem with the reactor, your career is over." And so we never had a problem with the reactors. That's what we need here. We need accountability. Even in their public sector, we need accountability.

WILLIS: Accountability, a big theme with you. You know, you called for her resignation. You're not backing off right now. Interesting. You've asked for documents though and what you want is a weekly report.

ALEXANDER: Sure.

WILLIS: What do you want to see?

ALEXANDER: Well, we want to know how many people have tried through the exchange to buy Obamacare, how many succeeded, in what zip code do they live, what level of insurance did they buy. We need to know that. We ought to know it every week. You know, before the internet age RCA knew how many records Elvis was selling every day. I mean, Ford knew how many cars it was selling every day. McDonald's could tell you how many hamburgers they're selling every day.

Now we're in the middle of the internet age, the Obama administration should be able to tell us every day how many people are signing up. What are they buying?

WILLIS: Doesn't the problems with the website tell you just how dramatic this is. She seems to be saying "We can't tell you. We don't know. We don't have the information." Do you buy that?

ALEXANDER: Well, if they don't know it is worse than I even think. The important thing is the website is not the biggest problem. The biggest problem is going to be the canceled premiums, the millions of Americans who are going to find on January 1 that the premiums that the president said they could keep are being canceled because they are not legal under Obamacare. These businesses are going to be finding that the costs are so high they're going to drop a lot of their coverage and their employees are going into Medicaid, and businesses are also struggling because of the 30- hour work week requirement. They're going to have to cut pay, in fact, by putting employees on 30-hour work weeks to avoid the Obamacare requirement.

WILLIS: What do you mean these premiums aren't legal?

ALEXANDER: What I mean is that under Obamacare only some insurance policies are legal. You may have an insurance policy with say a high deductible that you can afford and you like. The Obamacare may say that is as good enough for you, therefore that policy cannot be issued by an insurance company after January 1. So your policy is gone. So you then have to go on an exchange through a website that doesn't work to buy insurance or you will be fined by the Internal Revenue Service.

WILLIS: Senator, that is an issue we have been talking a lot about this week. Hundreds of thousands of people already seeing their policies canceled, and for that very reason they don't meet the requirements of the Obama administration.

ALEXANDER: That's more than hundreds of thousands. I mean, just in California, Florida, and New Jersey. We've counted up at least a million and a half Americans whose policies will be cancelled on January 1 which is about 10 times the number of people who applied for insurance in just those three states.

WILLIS: Astonishing fast. And as we look forward, one of the things we are hearing is that the costs are a big debate. We don't know how much this thing is costing us. Here's what Sebelius had to say today about what she has paid out for this website. Listen to this -

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BLACKBURN: Can you give me a ballpark of what you have spent on this website that does not work, that individuals can not get to. What is your cost estimate?

SEBELIUS: So far, Congresswoman, we have spent about $118 million on the website itself and about $56 million has been expended on other IT to support the web.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: So that's $174 million. In last week's testimony, the IT contractors themselves say they spent nearly 500 million. So who is right? What's the real number?

ALEXANDER: Well, I don't know. I've heard 400. But the fact is, this is the president's signature achievement. He has had three and half years to do it. I used to be a governor, that's smaller potatoes. But on something that is important to me, I put somebody in charge. I'll be with him every week or every month and say is it on budget. Is it getting done? And if it's not I'll get somebody else to do it. I don't know how why the president has not been doing that.

WILLIS: One final question, a couple of weeks ago, February 2010, you told the president "if you put this program in place you're going to raise people's premiums and it's going to cause people more money." He said, "You didn't have the facts straight." What is the reality?

ALEXANDER: Well, the reality was then I was right and today I am proven right because I said, "Mr. President, the Congressional Budget Office has said that individual premiums are going to go up under your claim. You don't know the facts." It turns out today individual premiums and there are 19 million Americans who have those, are seeing premium increases of maybe 50 percent to 100 percent.

WILLIS: But a long way to go. Senator, thanks for coming on the show tonight.

ALEXANDER: Thank you.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WILLIS: Coming up, the calls for Kathleen Sebelius to step down grow louder. Is the face of Obamacare ready to do that.

Next, this secretary isn't the only White House official in front of a camera today. The president also offering his take.

Our Rich Edson have the latest after the break.

ANNOUNCER: Live from Washington D.C., here again is Gerri Willis.

WILLIS: Welcome back to a special edition of "The Willis Report." We are live from our nation's capital. President Obama skipping out of town to sell his signature policy in Boston. The president eagerly trying to compare Massachusetts health care law's low start to Obamacare's, Fox Business' Rich Edson have the latest.

Rich, did the president comment on people losing their coverage?

RICH EDSON, FBN CORRESPONDENT: He did, Gerri, and it has become the primary criticism of the law this week, even overshadowing the botched rollout of healthcare.gov. President Obama said if Americans liked their substandard plans, they could have kept them. As for those who have seen their plans disappear, the president blamed insurance companies for canceling those policies. He then encourages Americans to find better Obamacare insurance.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

OBAMA: If you are getting one of these letters, just shop around in the new marketplace. That is what it's for. Because of the tax credits that we're offering and the competition between insurers, most people are going to be able to get better comprehensive health care plans for the same price or even cheaper than projected. You are going to get a better deal.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EDSON: Republicans say that the president lied when he was selling the proposal and that Americans largely cannot keep their cheaper, bare-bones insurance plans. The health care law was designed to phase out those policies, Gerri.

WILLIS: Rich, thank you. We appreciate your time.

Kathleen Sebelius sat in front of the House panel for three and a half long hours today, facing some tough questions. So what are the key takeaways? Let's get to it, joining me now, Avik Roy, senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute and AEI scholar Tom Miller. He is author of "Why Obamacare is Wrong for America." Avik, I will start with you. You were in the hearing, what did you make of it?

AVIK ROY, MANHATTAN INST.: I thought it was substantive. I thought there was a lot less of the grandstanding that you normally see at these kinds of hearings, but I think what I was struck by most of all was the depth and the scope and the breadth of the problems with the exchanges.

WILLIS: They were all over the place, it was everything from technical glitches to people losing their coverage. It was--

ROY: Front end, back-end, verifying with the IRS, the security and the privacy stuff that Congressman Rogers talked about that you played the clip of. It was just all over the place, and I look at this and I say, it is going to be a lot harder to fix this than I think a lot of people think.

WILLIS: I guess the problems are just starting, Tom. What did you make of the hearing?

TOM MILLER, AEI: What is coming out more and more is that problems with Obamacare are features, not bugs, it's not just a matter of technical incompetence. We've had plenty of that, but you start with the inability of people to access the site, but then we are learning about these other concerns, that the prices are a big problem for people, people are losing their plans, security and privacy are real concerns. There has been misleading information out on the web site, telling people between the ages of 27 and 50, here is the standard price for everyone, even though it's going to vary, same thing for 50 and above. All of these reflect that this was designed in a way different than what was sold to the American public. The president said you can keep your plan period, he forgot to say there was a semicolon. He had a few extra clauses which said there are other conditions on that one.

WILLIS: That is right. One of the things that nobody's talking about and really fascinates me, I don't feel that we really know Kathleen Sebelius, she is sort of a black box for a lot of us. We know she is not from around here. We know her dad was John Gilligan, who invented the state income tax, but beyond that, who is this woman running our health care?

ROY: I have written a lot about Kathleen Sebelius at my Forbes column and National Review, over the years, monitoring all the implementation of Obamacare, and what I can tell you is that she is arguably the most partisan operator at the cabinet level in the Obama administration. She has been very willing to change a lot of the things about the way that law is implemented, in order to maximize the political advantage of the administration. They postponed a lot of regulations dealing with the exchanges until after the election.

WILLIS: What about changing the shopping feature, that was politically motivated, Tom?

MILLER: And it came in just the last couple of weeks. They will try to throw the private contractors under the bus. They can't go too far or the private contractors will start revealing some private memos, which will not look very good. But that was a clear turnoff to keep people from knowing what the real prices were in order to induce them into the exchange and getting them--

WILLIS: One of the things people don't talk about, she is an old insurance commissioner, and that is often the job of someone who is very political, and somebody who really wants to hold the industry's feet to the fire.

MILLER: She believed in regulation as the insurance commissioner in Kansas. We think of Kansas as this deeply conservative state. She was on the other side of the divided both as the insurance commissioner and as the governor. So she is not only a second-hand manager, she is a believer in this. And a direct (inaudible).

WILLIS: You could hear in her voice, her commitment to this idea that everyone should get health care, that this is a national right. Is this a national right?

ROY: It is a particular kind of healthcare. Her view is that insurance means you have to be covered for every single thing, whereas normally in the business world, we think of insurance as you get hit by a bus, you have a stroke, you are covered. She thinks of insurance as everything should be paid for -- birth control, your allergy pills.

(CROSSTALK)

WILLIS: Someone said to me, while we had all these conversations, for so many months on Obamacare, if you wanted to get auto insurance, would you expect to go on the web and not tell anybody anything at all about your driving history? No, you would not, that would never happen, Tom, but that is exactly what is happening with Obamacare.

MILLER: Well, we passed the law without knowing what was in it. Now we have coverage where after you enroll, maybe you'll find out what's in it.

WILLIS: Absolutely right. Avik?

ROY: One of the things that is really important to understand about the architects of the law is they knew, they knew the web site was not ready, they knew eight months ago the web site wasn't ready. They only did the first end-to-end test of the web site one week before October 1, and yet they still launched the web site. And that is the question we didn't hear an answer to tonight or this morning. We didn't hear the answer to that question, you knew this web site was not ready yet you still launched it on October 1, why?

WILLIS: There was a great exchange today on that issue of end-to-end testing. Why didn't you take the website down, someone suggested, and test end-to-end, so you can figure out where the problems are. Fix it, repair it, get it back up, she said we're not stopping it. And that the point I made at the top of the show, which is it seems her message today was, I am sorry we have problems, I am sorry we have mistakes, issues along the way, but it doesn't matter. We're going full steam ahead, right, Tom?

MILLER: It was a politically driven operation. They knew what their political goals were first, the customers stood well behind that in terms of priorities, whether it was functional or not, they had to get something out on October 1. That drove all of the messiness and incomplete testing behind it.

ROY: People who do software for a living are pulling their hair out, because they are looking at those kinds of decisions and say, no competent IT process would eve be run this way. And this is the most important IT project in modern history.

WILLIS: And it is the most important consumer story, I believe, going on right now. Tom and Avik, thank you for being with us. You'll be back later. Appreciate your time. Stay with us.

When we come back, the truth behind these so-called glitches from the woman who helped redesign the WhiteHouse.gov under the Bush administration, she has great advice coming up.

WILLIS: Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius on the hot seat, as she battles to rebound from the flawed Obamacare rollout. So who exactly is Kathleen Sebelius and what does the future hold for her? We're back with Avik Roy from the Manhattan Institute and AEI scholar Tom Miller. Welcome back to both of you. You know, the conversation got heated several times, and it was funny, she got a little flustered a couple of times. I want you to hear this exchange between the secretary and Congressman Harper.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You are saying that the president is not responsible for HHS?

SEBELIUS: Sir, I didn't say that.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Okay, so the president ultimately is responsible -- while I think it is great you are a team player, and you are taking responsibility, it is the president's ultimate responsibility, correct?

SEBELIUS: You clearly -- whatever. Yes, he is the president, he is responsible for government programs.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: Tom, is it all about accountability here? Is it all about where the buck stops? I think she was trying to say, Sebelius today, that it stops with me, but I have a sense this was all for show?

MILLER: Well, this is the unaccountable care act, done politically at least. Kathleen Sebelius is making a virtue out of her ignorance. As long as she can say I don't really know anything about this technology, you don't have to look any further under the hood. But she is also there to serve the president. She is the heat shield, because if she's not in the way, people say to the man in the White House, did Bo chew your homework, or what did you do in terms of administrating the country?

WILLIS: Certainly the spotlight goes back on the president. Big question tonight, a lot of people are asking, should she resign?

ROY: The president said last week, it is not just a web site, Obamacare is not just a web site, it is a whole law that changes the health care system. Republicans agree. It's not just a web site. It is the underlying architectural law, and if you replace Kathleen Sebelius, the flawed architectural law would still exist. So I don't see what that accomplishes, frankly.

WILLIS: Well, she's going to lead this, she's going to take heat, would it be better to have somebody else in the job?

MILLER: You can't confirm a full-time secretary in this political environment. So you lose technically the ability--

WILLIS: No way to get that done.

MILLER: You need votes.

WILLIS: Can't get it done--

(CROSSTALK)

MILLER: -- more rounds of hearings about how HHS is run.

WILLIS: So at the end of the day, she is going to keep her job, at least for the present, and she is going to be in charge of fixing what she has not been able to put in place for three years.

ROY: And that is why she can say I am responsible for this debacle, because she's secure in her job, she knows she can take the arrows and she has the confidence of the president. But, will she fix it? She can't, she is responsible, she is -- the White House and HHS are both responsible for this mess, because that October 1 launch date, that was the White House's decision to say we're going to stick to this October 1 launch date, even if we're not ready, even if everyone tells us we're not ready.

MILLER: There is another launch date, which is January 1st, where people have lost their coverage, and where the exchange coverage begins. I believe that the president will carry out a time honored tradition, on opening day he throws out the first scapegoat, and it might be Kathleen Sebelius.

ROY: It's kind of like Macbeth. Macbeth says, well, my hands are bloodied, so should I just kill everyone else or should I just stop now. And I think they are at the I'm going to kill everyone else day.

WILLIS: You are gleeful in what's going on, which is a tragedy for the American people. We were talking earlier in the show about hundreds of thousands of people losing their coverage tonight. California, Florida, all over the country. Tom, to you, this is playing out in the living rooms now.

ROY: It's real.

WILLIS: Not just a congressional hearing, that is in fact just a television set, let's face it, this is a real story.

MILLER: And that is what changes this from I'm going to give you another speech, I'm going to tell you what is coming, here is what it's going to be. Instead it all of a sudden shows up in the daily lives of the average Americans, even the loss of coverage thing that's due to the grandfathering rules, it's actually due to a lot of the provisions in the law, which are literally outlawing coverage, whether or not you are grandfathered. There are other requirements in the law which means that these old individual plans no longer qualify as legitimate plans in the marketplace.

WILLIS: And we've certainly seen a lot of that. As I was saying, hundreds of thousands of people losing their coverage, but not everyone wants coverage in case they get pregnant, or mental health coverage.

ROY: To your point about how this is a living room issue now, the politics are a lose-lose for the administration. If they were to shut down the web site, there would be a temporary humiliation, but the American people would be better off, the American people would be better off if we delayed this law, get the web site rebuilt, allow people to have their existing coverage until the new law is built out. They don't want to do that, and that is a real problem, and I think a lot of people will be upset about this.

WILLIS: I think we have to move to a conversation about solutions, because it is really not enough to say this is not working, we don't like it, we don't like the president, that's a really -- that's boring, right? What do you do to fix it?

MILLER: There are short-term patches, they are difficult though because the law, the provisions are so interrelated. You move this over here, you create a problem somewhere else. You can change the mandate date, or delay it, then that affects some of the coverage projections. So you can expand the enrollment period, same problem. So what you probably have got to do, which we don't have the leverage for, is to say if there is a plan on the marketplace that you used to buy before, you can keep it, and it can still be a valid plan. That is the first step. You make this a lot less complex.

WILLIS: Today she said I'm not doing that, we're not going to do that. We're not going to extend the enrollment period. You cannot have a 12 month enrollment period.

ROY: There has been a bill introduced by Senator Ron Johnson of Wisconsin, he has introduced a bill that is also being introduced by Upton in the Energy and Commerce Committee, to say if you had a plan in 2013 that was legal, you can keep it in 2014. And if -- there are a couple of Democrats in the Senate, Mary Landrieu announced she is in favor of that approach. So I think you might see something like that get through Congress.

WILLIS: Well, we'll have to wait and see. I know that secretary of health and human services does not like it. Maybe there will be cooler heads that prevail.

MILLER: Security Sebelius will feel comfortable and secure in her job until the president says, you are doing a heck of a job, Kathleen.

WILLIS: Thank you for being on, Avik and Tom. Great job, thanks so much.

Still to come, my two cents more, and Secretary Sebelius says Obamacare web site has been miserably frustrating, but it has not crashed. We'll separate fact from fiction with the former White House chief information officer. You want to see that, coming up.

WILLIS: Countless Americans are struggling to find quality, affordable health care coverage on the Obamacare web site. Americans like 62-year-old David Byron (ph), who last night on our show told us it took days to navigate all the glitches, and he is now on hold for another 45 days. Meanwhile, here in Washington, politicians are debating whether the web site problems are really all that bad.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The program has crashed and burned at least three times, it has been down the whole time you've been testifying, the system is down at this moment.

SEBELIUS: I would suggest that the web site has never crashed.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: Joining me now Theresa Payton, former White House chief information officer under President George W. Bush. She was tasked with redesigning the WhiteHouse.Gov web site. Theresa, thank you for joining us. I have to ask you, how in the world can you say that this web site has not crashed?

THERESA PAYTON, FORMER WH CHIEF INFORMATION OFFICER: I think this is very difficult. You know, a lot of times techies get caught up in the site didn't crash, it is actually that the site is just slow or a form is not working. And in this case, if you think about it, the customer is king here, and what we learned at the White House is, if they came to the site, could not get the information they wanted, in their mind it crashed.

WILLIS: Exactly. I think that is what so many people take away. And during the entire hearing, practically, the site was down. So it was right there in front of everyone to see. Shocking, the other big tech question, everybody was talking about it, was privacy. I'm sure as you know, there was a language buried deep in the web site, that said you really can't trust this site to keep your privacy safe. Sebelius countered that. Here is what she said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEBELIUS: That is boilerplate language that should not have been in this particular contract, because there are the highest security standards are in place, and people have every right to expect privacy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: So Theresa, she said we are going to get rid of this. It will not be on the web site anymore, but does that mean we're safe or does that mean a line of code they just got rid of? What does it mean?

PAYTON: I think this is more complicated than that. You are absolutely right. And on the first thing, I was glad to hear her say, we have a right to expect privacy. So I hope, to get customer confidence back, they will actually create a privacy policy we can all read and understand. And it should be front and center on this web site.

The second piece, is even a great privacy and security policy does not mean that the web site is not hackable. So, people need to take precautions and keep that in mind as they are putting information on the web site.

WILLIS: Theresa, isn't it true, I just read this today, they are having problems with a password reset that is causing an opportunity for hackers out there, and from I read in the trades, what they are saying is it's not unusual that there is a problem. The problem is that they have not found it yet, and why was it not fixed, why was it not fixed immediately. What do you say to that?

PAYTON: Well, you know, one thing that I learned in my time at Banking and at the White House is, time and testing can be your best friend or your worst enemy. It sounds like they feel they did not have enough time to actually test.

In this situation, with the password reset, one of the things that we can't control is some of these bugs in the system. So a piece of advice I have for everyone is, there will be other bugs, it could put your data at risk. So go ahead and get a unique e-mail address that is not attached to your bank account or the rest of your life, and use that unique e-mail address just for health care. That way if the bad guys get in, and get your data, it is going to be harder for them to take over the rest of your accounts online.

WILLIS: Theresa, that is great advice. I want to play one more piece of sound, this is Congressman Rogers asking Sebelius about testing. Here it is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Has each piece of that code that has been introduced in the system been security tested?

SEBELIUS: That is my understanding, yes, sir.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Each piece of that code has been tested? Yes or no.

SEBELIUS: I don't know.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: What do you make of that, Theresa? It sounds like she is confused about what they've done, what they haven't done. Were you surprised?

PAYTON: I was a little surprised, because any program manager worth their weight would make sure there was a good full testing plan. And there are automated testing tools, it does not just require bodies these days. You can actually program testing tools to test all kinds of scenarios. So I think one of the questions that needs to be asked, is how do you answer the testing questions to the satisfaction for the security team, and do we have data in grave danger of either being corrupted or stolen? I think that is a key question that needs to be answered.

WILLIS: And not answered yet. So many questions, so few answers on the technical difficulties with the web site. Theresa, thanks for coming in tonight and chatting with us about it. We appreciate your time.

PAYTON: Thanks for having me.

WILLIS: We'll be right back with my two cents more and the answer to the question of the day, do you buy Sebelius' apology? Stay with us.

WILLIS: Finally tonight, kudos to Kathleen Sebelius for admitting her role in the debacle that is the Obamacare web site. But now to the people's problem, since the site does not work and people cannot get on the site to fulfill the requirements of the law, why wouldn't we delay the mandate further? When the administration can't get the centerpiece of its key program working in the middle of a congressional hearing on its lack of competency, well, that is a sign that continuing to push forward makes no sense. But the administration is not waiting. Sorry we screwed up, but there will be no delays in the mandate. Apology for the mistake, but you'll still face penalties if you do not apply. We're taking responsibility for our screwups, but we are forging ahead anyway, sorry.

I'm reminded what the secretary muttered under her breath as the congressman began to ask her why she had not applied for coverage -- don't do this to me, she said. Indeed, don't do this to us. That's my two cents more. And that's it for tonight's WILLIS REPORT. Thanks for joining us. We'll see you right here. Well, not right here, but in New York tomorrow. Have a good night.
