Smith, Keith Fitz-Gerald, Jonas Max FerrisNEWSBusiness041101cb.223Sebelius Resigns; Interview with Tom DeLay; Biz BlitzNeil Cavuto, David Asman

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KATHLEEN SEBELIUS, HHS SECRETARY: I got to be a leader of HHS during this most historic times. We are on the frontlines of a long overdue national change, fixing a broken health system. Now this is the most meaningful work I've ever been a part of. In fact, it's been the cause of my life.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN HOST: Well, not anymore. Because Sebelius is out and look who's coming in. Welcome everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto. And maybe Republicans should stop high fiving each other over this Kathleen Sebelius resignation over at HHS.

And take a gander at who is quickly filling the void for HHS, not the woman yet to be confirmed there but the folks already up and running at the IRS. Yes, the IRS. It's true and it is kind of frightening because the Internal Revenue Service now it's carte blanche to kind of do anything. Are you surprised?

Don't be. The IRS is already knee deep in this healthcare thing. Policing it, hiring agents to enforce it, monitoring virtually all financing aspects of it. Yes, the taxman, better known to conservatives are targeting them, now the default go to healthcare law enforcers, monitoring us, all of us. So talk about taxing and talk about out of the frying pan and into another federal agency fire. Maybe a worse one.

To former Governor Mike Huckabee, former Health & Human Services Secretary Tommy Thompson on why this gap could be an even bigger slap. Governor Huckabee, what do you think?

FMR. GOV. MIKE HUCKABEE, ARKANSAS: Well, I think the IRS issue is a huge one because you got one of the most powerful government agencies that have information on every citizen in this country and for them to take the power that they have and use it to crush people whose views they don't like, I think turns the IRS into a criminal enterprise. I know that strong word but I think that's exactly what it has become and the reason that we have to get to the bottom of it is because if you can't trust an agency of the federal government without much power, you really lost trust in the federal government completely.

CAVUTO: But, you know, a lot of people, if you think about it, Secretary, lost for us HHS and they might be attained with this switch in leaders but the fact of the matter is this is going to be a learning curve and in the middle of that curve is the IRS who (INAUDIBLE) up and running, already doing a lot of this administrative healthcare law. What do you think of that?

TOMMY THOMPSON, FMR. HHS SECRETARY: Well, I'm very concerned about is as Governor Huckabee has just indicated, the IRS seems to be off the reservation, being investigated by Congress in many different ways. Lois Lerner refuses to answer any questions and the attorney general says they are investigating but we all know that Benghazi and the armed situation in Mexico, the bait-and-switch operation, the conservatives that have been attacked by IRS, all indicate to me the IRS is not the agency to be running healthcare in America.

CAVUTO: But it is now. But it is, right? And governor, it is the default (INAUDIBLE) for this because but there are no others doing it for the time being and yet they are the ones collecting revenue and policing to how it's going to be enforced (INAUDIBLE) those who didn't pay right now, make sure they better pay. There is a lot of power here.

THOMPSON: 16,000 employees have been hired by IRS to do the policing of this. If you think that your taxes are going to be audited wait until you have 16,000 individuals who are on America whose only job is to find people that are not signing up for health care. I think it's an awesome power, an awesome responsibility and it's going to cause a lot of concern as Governor Huckabee has said across America.

CAVUTO: Yes, not exactly awesome to us though, is it.

HUCKABEE: Well, one of the concerns that we have to have is the privacy issue. Think about the IRS having detailed medical information about people who are qualifying for certain federal subsidies, or they have the opportunity to have access to data. It's really is none of their business. Now this is an agency that leased out information regarding the International Organization for Marriage and their donors, that blew up horribly for the NON and so you've already found that the IRS can't keep a secret.

How can you possibly trust them with people's health care records? It is outrageous.

CAVUTO: You know, secretary, are you going to expect any changes now with the new head coming in, presumably she's not going to encounter that much resistance taking over HHS? Or is it still going to be much the same? The underlying problem is the underlying law itself.

THOMPSON: Well, the problem has always been with (INAUDIBLE) is that the White House runs it but they never really gave Kathleen Sebelius the opportunity. They blamed her and they put her as the face of Affordable Care but it's truly the White House who is doing it.

I believe the new secretary is going to have more powers to make changes because I think she probably requested it of the president. But there is still going to be a continuation because in the rule - in the law that was passed, the second law that was passed, people really don't understand this, Neil, that the first law that was passed in Congress, that was signed into law did not work.

So they had to pass a remedial bill that gave awesome powers to the secretary over 1,000 shelves are in that particular bill and those proclamation, that rule making is going to continue under the new secretary as it did under the old and that is really one of the problems with the Affordable Care Act.

CAVUTO: Which you argued as the problem itself, the law itself, right?

HUCKABEE: Well, it's the law itself. Kathleen Sebelius is like the astronauts sitting on top of the rocket. She's sitting there on top of $100 million worth of equipment designed by the lowest bidder. And so in many ways she can't be blamed for everything that was sitting up under her. I do think she could be faulted for going out there and giving the Pollyanna, everything is coming up roses speech all the time and not being more honest but I've known Kathleen as a governor. She was an insurance commissioner. She knew better.

But I think she was doing the work of the administration. They put her in an impossible situation. They gave her a car that wouldn't drive. No wonder she couldn't drive it.

CAVUTO: Guys, thank you both, very much. We'll watch closely.

We got a lot more coming. Who do you think Harry Reid is really worried about these days? What if I told you, not this guy. What if I told you these guys. Then I heard of pay to play but pay to quit. You look at Amazon and not really into it, Bill cut you a check to leave it. How big a check would your boss have to write to get you to chuck it. We're on it.

And Tom Delay now smelling blood and telling Republicans don't you dare give an inch.

CAVUTO: Well, now they are saying nice things about her. Weeks ago, they were demanding her head. Now Republicans (INAUDIBLE) their best wishes as Sebelius just heads out. Congressman Darryl Issa, "Kathleen Sebelius had a supremely difficult job." Eric Cantor posting on Twitter "I thank Secretary Sebelius for her service. She had an impossible task." Senator Orrin Hatch, "Secretary Sebelius did the best she could during the tumultuous and volatile roll out of the law."

With me now, Center for American Progress' Emily Tisch Sussman. Emily, what do you make of this? Obviously, they're quietly delighted she is gone but maybe getting a little ahead of themselves? What?

EMILY TISCH SUSSMAN, CENTER FOR AMERICAN PROGRESS: Yes, well, first, I think it's very nice they're not asking her to hit the door on the way out, nicely giving her some compliment on her way out.

CAVUTO: Actually one of them did. I left that one out. But you're right, most of them were pretty nice.

SUSSMAN: That's very nice. I think that one, they are setting themselves up to actually have a pretty smooth confirmation process. You know, for the next nominee who is coming in from OMB. I think they don't want to have a tough fight around that. I think they're setting themselves up for that. But I also think that there was an acknowledgement that Secretary Sebelius had an extremely difficult task as they had mentioned.

But one of the things I think (INAUDIBLE) talked about as much is the fact that she actually went out, went beyond the politics and reached out to Republican governors to go state by state and try to convince them to actually take the Medicaid expansion.

CAVUTO: You know, I'm always wanting - you know, they always look for a sacrificial lamb every time they force someone out or want to force someone out but she did not strike me as being up on old details of the law but then again, neither did her bosses at the White House. So I'm just wondering whether just changing ahead of an agency is really going to change all the problem we had seen with this law or do we take Steny Hoyer and his word, who was here not too long ago, saying, you give this thing time. Things are going to get better. They are getting better. What do you think?

SUSSMAN: Look, I think that she left at a natural point. It wasn't like she was forced out and by all accounts the president didn't ask her to step down. She offered to step down. She has been there from the beginning.

CAVUTO: Wait a minute. She said - is this the first time she offered to step down because sometimes - is this the first time she offered to step down because sometimes when someone offers that - like I offered to resign every day and "Neil, you can't go. Please no. No."

SUSSMAN: They haven't taken you up yet.

CAVUTO: No. When they take you up on it is when you get nervous. So obviously they didn't wait a nanosecond to say "Oh, you got to go. OK. Bye."

SUSSMAN: Look, she has outlasted all of the major cabinet positions with the exception of Holder and Arne Duncan. She has lasted every major milestone. She's been there. She is really - she has had her slug through. This is a natural point. They announced last week -

CAVUTO: What is the natural point? Post the number of enrollees that they announced?

SUSSMAN: Exactly.

CAVUTO: After that she could go.

SUSSMAN: Certainly. You know, at the end of the first open enrolment period -

CAVUTO: Right.

SUSSMAN: They were aiming for 7.1 million enrollees. They hit 7.5. It's an estimation that it's 10 million that weren't insured before, now have insurance. This is the natural point for (INAUDIBLE) turnover.

CAVUTO: Well those are debatable. Those are debatable numbers, right? I mean, we talked about how many paid? How many really are real?

SUSSMAN: Neil, all of that will come out. We'll see that in the next - I mean -

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: But you think better news (INAUDIBLE) I hear what you're saying. What you're saying better news is ahead and these Republicans who were delighting in her departure, Sebelius' departure, might be getting ahead of themselves, right?

SUSSMAN: You know, I think that's true. They've been so hard on there's no compromise. There's no way to work out the law. It's repeal, repeal, repeal. It's over. I think politically that moment has passed. Now you need to look at what is maybe not working so well and move - you know, as any major law.

CAVUTO: Yes.

SUSSMAN: This is not a surprise that there are pieces of the law that need to be adjusted as you go. That's to be expected.

CAVUTO: Are you surprised though that even with - let's say the news is looking better. That a lot of vulnerable Democrats running for re-election are avoiding it like the plague, still?

SUSSMAN: Well, I think they are looking at poll by poll in their state but many of them aren't. Many of them are running on the law.

CAVUTO: Who? Who's running on it? Who is making it their cause?

SUSSMAN: Look, I think we have to look no further than Arkansas and just say that, you know, Prior is saying this has been something that has been good for Arkansas. I also think when we're talking about the politics, let's look at the Republicans state governors who have gone through and who have now accepted the Medicaid expansion, particularly Ohio with Kasik there, Gov. Jan Brewer in Arizona. Though she's not running for re- election now. But Kasik and Corben in Pennsylvania.

CAVUTO: Well, you raised a good point.

SUSSMAN: These are governors -

CAVUTO: You raised a good point.

(CROSSTALK)

SUSSMAN: Not only (INAUDIBLE) protest they have larger ambitions. They must think that this is politically great for them.

CAVUTO: It's also easy money.

SUSSMAN: Never a problem there.

CAVUTO: Emily Tisch Sussman, thank you. Very good seeing you again.

And next, paying dollars to get dead weight out the door. Well Amazon is trying to (INAUDIBLE) for it. Then the politician who's got a serious coke addiction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. HARRY REID, HOUSE SPEAKER: Mr. President, you know, I'm not afraid of this Coke Brothers, Coke Brothers, Coke Brothers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: All right. I want you to meet the guest who says "Harry, you have got to get over this Coke fix."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REID: Coke Brothers, Coke Brothers, Coke Brothers, Coke Brothers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: So not into working at Amazon, how about a $5,000 check to get you to quit Amazon. Don't laugh. Amazon is quite serious, convinced that paying workers who aren't all that into their job, to leave their job, helps keep workers who remain jazzed in their jobs.

Steve Odland, the former Office Depot chairman on whether this makes good business sense and radio host, political sensation Gina Loudon on whether it makes good people cents. The people part first. It doesn't make sense.

GINA LOUDON, PH.D., RADIO HOST & AUTHOR: You know, this is public relations. I don't know how long ago it was but I was on your show and we were talking about the drones. Remember they're going to be delivering packages by drones. We had the Microsoft (INAUDIBLE), we've had these incidences come up again and again. And this is for publicity. The thing I kind of like about this one is it is actually doable. Delivering packages by drone, probably not doable and the Microsoft bra - I don't even know what was going on with that. But this is actually something that -

CAVUTO: I'm remembering a Microsoft (INAUDIBLE), not doable?

LOUDON: Well, OK. Maybe but not. It was a publicity stand.

CAVUTO: Understand.

LOUDON: Even though this is a publicity stunt, at least it is something that is truly applicable and doable for the (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: All right. Steve, I'm back to Amazon and paying people to just, you know, take a hike. What do you think of that?

STEVE ODLAND, FMR. OFFICE DEPOT CEO: Well, this is not a publicity stand. This is something that has been in place at Zappos.com for quite some time and they're CEO Tony Hsieh implemented this many years ago and I had a chance to meet with him and they got a chance to get people to stand back and say "Look, are you happy? Are you not happy? If you're not happy, why? But here's an incentive for you to go, if you're not.

And the kids -

CAVUTO: Well how much is it? How much are they paying because Zappos, if my memory serves me right, they sell shoes online, right? I mean, I get such really good shoes, you're going to be passionate about. If you're not maybe (INAUDIBLE). But did it work?

ODLAND: So, well, it worked fine and they had a really interesting culture and then Zappos now had been purchased by Amazon. So the sub story here is that this is very unusual for an acquiring company, particularly a bigger one like Amazon to adopt a procedure or a policy that was in a company that they acquired and I think what Jeff Bezos should be applauded for is taking this and introducing it to Amazon.

The fact is very few employees actually take advantage of it but it does give them a chance to stand back and to reassess on whether they are happy because the whole point is if you're not happy you're not going to be giving the customer service that you want to happen in the company and therefore you're better off having those unhappy people leave.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: In Bezos' case, he just (INAUDIBLE) the "Washington Post," I can guarantee you half of those guys are miserable. Just because that's their disposition.

LOUDON: But that's why - you know, the psychology, the reverse psychology of this actually were is that it is fascinating here because it does - you know, my background is in organizational development and this does boost employee morale. It gives people permission to go, to make a decision on a yearly basis, am I happy? Am I not happy? And so they're going to be -

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Why offer them a check? I mean, Jack Welch was saying this for the GE days of weeding out the dead wood or those who really weren't jazz because he thought negative attitudes were contagious and all and just got rid of them. They didn't offer a check to leave the door, just said you're out.

LOUDON: It's a very polite way to show people the door if they want to take it -

CAVUTO: But if you're earning 50,000 a year and you are given a check for 5,000 to leave your job, you're not going to take a $5,000 check?

LOUDON: No, of course not. But the point is that you could. So it gives that employee that internal sense of that locus of control. They feel more in control, they're generally more content in their work and they're going to tend, probably stay longer and have better positive employee (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: I see. It makes sense. But Steve, I always think that I know what Amazon was trying to do here. They want to (INAUDIBLE) and engage workforce and the not so subtle message here is if you're not jazz, you're not into it. Here's 5,000 bucks and get the heck out of here. But what if it doesn't work and they're offering this and people don't take them up on it. Is that when the firing start?

ODLAND: Well, you know, I'm sure that they do terminate people or they manage people out as well but I think it's much better to have a caring approach versus the stick approach. The stick approach teaches -

CAVUTO: Again, Steve, how would a $5,000 check do that?

ODLAND: It's because it allows and the conversation to happen in a positive way and people, you know, to raise their hand and say, you know, I'm going to take this and I'm going to go. And it gives people the chance to, you know, supervises the change to say to them "Look, do you want to take advantage of this thing?" So there's some subtle encouragement. It's the carrot rather than saying there's a culture of fear where we're going to fire you.

CAVUTO: What if they get workman's compensation if they do that?

LOUDON: In a $50,000 a year job, it's more than care, it's more like a cupcake. I know you can relate to that. Right?

CAVUTO: That has no meaning to be such a (INAUDIBLE).

So you think that if done properly this could work?

LOUDON: I think if done properly what this does is boost morale on a regular basis.

CAVUTO: Well, what do you think of the surviving workers then. See, their buddies go with a $5,000 check?

LOUDON: It's better than seeing their buddies go with nothing.

CAVUTO: Maybe they're getting more work to do.

LOUDON: It's better than their buddies go with nothing and they can always, you know, hire more people. We need jobs out there.

CAVUTO: What do you think of that? I mean, if they go, Steve, then the remaining workers are stuck doing the losers' jobs, right?

ODLAND: Yes, but they have the opportunity to go.

CAVUTO: OK.

ODLAND: So I think, net-net, it's a positive thing because it ends up with a more committed work force, somebody who has thought through and who said, you know, I really want to be here.

CAVUTO: Right. Well, I think Gina is on to something if they pay them all with food. I mean, I don't know. We could be talking something here.

Guys, thank you both very much.

LOUDON: Thank you.

CAVUTO: Meanwhile, (INAUDIBLE) 35 hour workweek then mandatory vacation at totaling at least five weeks and now no more e-mails after 6:00 p.m. any day, any week, always. The new law that makes me think the over the top arrogant dude in that Cadillac ad might be right on.

But first, it's hammer time. Tom Delay delighted that she's out, now telling Republicans man, up. And when it comes to this health care law don't give Democrats an inch.

CAVUTO: Well, forget about trying to make it to work. Tom Delay is telling Republicans to do with the law what they (INAUDIBLE) due to the woman who was in charge of that law, making history too. The former Republican leader joining me now.

So Tom, your essential message, you've said this before. You've been consistent. Hang tough, be tough, don't do anything to keep this thing going, right?

TOM DELAY, FMR. HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: That's exactly right. First of all, Neil, the federal government being involved in health insurance is unconstitutional. And not only that but has whole Obamacare has been based on the wrong premise. You want the federal government to get in to running our health care system and create a huge new entitlement program, all for the sake of however many people don't have insurance who have chosen not to have insurance.

And Nancy Pelosi said yesterday, and it's just amazing to me that she was very proud of Sebelius for creating a right of health care for the federal government and for the American people. Healthcare is not a right, it's a responsibility and it needs to be repelled. It doesn't need to be fixed. And it doesn't need to be replaced. It needs to be repealed.

CAVUTO: You know, (INAUDIBLE) if you ever see the former speaker, Tom, is to keep calling it Obamacare. It drives her nuts. Affordable Care, Affordable Care. So it just drives her nuts. So if I ever bump into her, I always say Obamacare, Obamacare.

Anyway, do you think that when Republicans were working with these provisions that would drop some of the burdens and rules and access regulations off of small businesses, even though they were doing it ostensibly to help those businesses - it was done by a voice vote too which was weird, the unintended consequences that was keeping this thing going longer.

DELAY: Well, I'm not sure about that. If there is no mandate for small businesses, that is repealing the law step-by-step, we could do it that way or do it wholesale but taking the mandatory out of the small business, and I would like to see them take the mandatory out for individuals that eviscerates the law. You don't have much of a law anymore.

CAVUTO: So when Robert Gibbs was talking about removing that mandate or very likely that the businessman that would go and that got Nancy Pelosi almost as upset as saying Obamacare, Obamacare, Obamacare. That got her annoyed. What do you make of that and what he was more or less acknowledging?

DELAY: Well, he was acknowledging that they were taking Obamacare apart piece by piece. The next piece that needs to be taken out is the entitlement part. People aren't paying attention that most of the people that have signed up are getting subsidies. This is a new entitlement, just like Medicare or Medicaid, especially Medicaid. Both of those are going to bankrupt us and bankrupt the state if we don't do something about it. And now we're layering another one and where all these people are getting subsidies from the American taxpayer. This just can't be sustained unless we want to replace it with single payer government runs everything like Europe or Canada, and that will be the end of our health care system.

CAVUTO: I don't want to sound jaded or -- I think that that was their intention all along, that insurance companies quite naturally would have to start upping and hiking their rates to cover all the new additions, and that the administration foresaw this, saw the people would be getting angry at insurance companies for doing that. And ultimately we will go in that direction. And then what?

DELAY: That is where they are headed. And now they want to invite the Republicans in to fix it and going to make that part of the campaign this year.

CAVUTO: Well, what would you do?

DELAY: What I would do is elect Republicans to the Senate, as many as you can get over there in the Senate. Elect some more good, solid conservatives in the House, and just start throwing repeals to Obama for the next two years and make sure that this Obamacare is a major part in the next presidential election. That is what I would do.

CAVUTO: In the meantime, the administration is crowing about they are getting more and more people signing up for this, more and more people signing up for Medicaid, it might be for the various reasons that you alluded to, that they are switching from one government program to another, and taxing Americans in the process. But that the trend will be their friend, and actually come November, it might not be that big of an issue, or the issue that Republicans hope. What do you think?

DELAY: That's just not going to happen. You're going to have more bad stuff. Every month, there is another bad news about this. Even the national media cannot avoid telling the American people about it, and you can bet that those millions that are getting their health care insurance canceled are telling their friends. This election has been set, and the American people have lost all trust in this president, have lost all trust in the Democrats. They have no credibility. If the Republicans don't screw it up, this is going to be another wave election.

CAVUTO: Let's see. They have grabbed defeat from the jaws of victory in the past, you know.

DELAY: Well, 2010 was a good election. And the American people have had it. Have had it. And they don't want any more of it. And anyone that has had anything to do with it is going to be thrown out if we have a good opponent against them.

CAVUTO: We'll watch closely. Tom DeLay, it's always a pleasure.

DELAY: Thank you, Neil. It's great to be with you.

CAVUTO: Meanwhile, maybe the guy in that Cadillac ad was right.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Other countries, they work, they stroll home, they stop by the cafe. They take August off. Off. Why aren't you like that? Why aren't we like that? Because we're crazy, driven, hard working believers, that's why.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: I love it when he just acknowledges the other child. Anyway, maybe that is why the rest of the world really are a bunch of wusses. Because something the French just did sacre bleu my mind.

CAVUTO: Time for our viewerr (ph) segment, or should I say le viewer (ph). Tonight a French twist, because for the folks not exactly big on work, a move that proves these guys, who for some reason like to plop an egg on everything, really are a piece of work. France wants to ban email, all e- mails after 6:00 p.m., says it just gets in the way of family life and gets in the way of sipping a latte at the cafe for hours at a time and ignoring your family. But (inaudible) tweets this is a sure bet to make French employees even more unproductive. Still another from Leneck (ph). Just more senseless regulation. That's why their economy is in la (inaudible). And finally, (inaudible) who tweets, Neil, I cannot comment. Must be after 6:00 p.m. somewhere. That's very clever.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: What do you make of this?

DAVID ASMAN, FBN: I think it's great news for us, the competitors. Anybody who competes with the French, this is great news. We love to work. What they call our greed and our type A personality, we call good work. You work hard and it helps you get ahead, helps you move up. It also helps you get as much money as you can possibly get. I don't think that's a bad thing, but apparently they do.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: We're missing life. We're in such a rush.

ASMAN: What is scary though is the extent to which this administration and a lot of people in America now want us to move us towards the French way in terms of health care. (inaudible), remember when that CBO report came out saying Americans are going to work less because of Obamacare? The administration said, that is great. They could become poets. They could move to France and drink latte at the cafes. That ain't what makes the American dream, brother.

CAVUTO: But you know, you and I can remember a time when you went on vacation, no one bothered you. Now you have to have your device with you. Maybe they're on to something.

ASMAN: You and I can remember a lot of times we should've forgotten long ago. You know what I'm saying?

[LAUGHTER]

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Somehow I can picture that. But this idea where we are 24/7 working, and we're on, our gadgets are on, we have to be on, we have to be engaged, the French just don't see it.

ASMAN: The greatest thing about America is not necessarily the people who were born here, but the immigrants that come here, and they work 14 to 18 hours a day. You better believe they wouldn't accept these French rules. In fact, some of the immigrants are probably from France.

People who come here and appreciate the fact that if you work here, you get rewards. I guess over there, you have such high tax rates, if you work hard, eventually doesn't pay to work that much. So maybe you should sit back...

CAVUTO: I think that is a profound point right there.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Issue two, almost as maddening as the French.

A guy who's just as fried, Harry Reid, look at this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. HARRY REID, D-NEV.: Mr. President, I am not afraid of the Koch brothers.

Koch brothers--

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: The Senate majority leader apparently thinking that the Koch brothers are a bigger threat than Vladimir Putin could ever be. It's true. In an analysis of Nevada Democrat's public comments last month, the Koch brothers were mentioned 65 times. Vlad apparently only once. That's got our Twitter followers going nuts. One writing it is Senator Harry Reid who is the biggest threat to the United States. Another, no, George Soros is the biggest threat. One more from Nac (ph). Phrasing it in a different way. Who is the bigger threat to Harry Reid's job? What do you make of that?

ASMAN: The Democrats have failed miserably to stop the advance of our enemy, and I think Vladimir Putin is our enemy. At least right now he is. Maybe he'll switch eventually. But they have succeeded very well in lambasting people who have created 60,000 jobs. Koch Industries, 60,000. By the way, many of those jobs are union jobs, I think about a third of them are union. So they are friends to unions as well, and they have given away hundreds of millions, I am not exaggerating.

CAVUTO: It was George Soros who is just as influential, if not more so. He's influential and more so on the left.

ASMAN: But they make George Soros look like a piker when it comes to giving money to good causes. I'm not talking about political causes here. They just gave $100 million to a hospital after which, by the way, Harry Reid got on the floor and said, they're taking advantage of the poor cancer patients by using them and exploiting them. The fact is, they gave $100 million to the Presbyterian Hospital here in New York.

CAVUTO: But you can't pick and choose your billionaires and their causes, right? I mean, if you're OK with George Soros doing what he's doing, simply because he gives to liberal causes, which you like, shouldn't you lump him with the Koch brothers, then, if that's going to be your--

(CROSSTALK)

ASMAN: If you're honest, you have to do that. But what really gets me about Harry Reid is him calling these people and I am quoting now, as un- American as anyone that I can imagine. What is un-American about building a huge enterprise that employs 60,000 people? What is un-American about giving $100 million to a hospital, $600 million to various institutions in New York, including a lot of artsy-fartsy stuff that you like.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: -- the way they go after Sheldon Adelson, a big Republican--

ASMAN: From Las Vegas.

CAVUTO: That any of them are bad, any of them are bad, but the left leaning billionaires that give to causes that they like, they're never going to be cited.

ASMAN: So why are you looking for consistency with their arguments? There is none!

CAVUTO: There really is none at all.

ASMAN: I haven't seen it. And you pointed out just one of many inconsistent examples.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: -- move to France and cut off everything at 6:00 p.m.?

ASMAN: Well, because they don't want to lose their billions. You know, they have this millionaire tax over in France. I think, in fact, there are a lot of nothing will turn someone into a conservative more than a high tax rate. That is what happened in England, that's what happened in Sweden. They went from a socialist government to give it to a free-market government, and maybe it will happen here too.

CAVUTO: (inaudible), word of warning. They put eggs on everything. Meanwhile, coming up, former secretary of state, Condy Rice, just landed a very big job at a very big tech firm. But the critics have already started an Internet campaign against it and her. Find out why. But first, that refund you've been waiting for? I hate to break it to you, the IRS has already cashed a check. Not because you owe them money, but because your parents do. I'm not kidding, kids. Blame it on pops, kid. But apparently, it is all perfectly legal. Kids.

CAVUTO: In tonight's Biz Blitz, getting hosed at the IRS, and you really don't have to be a conservative, just a taxpayer whose parents owe money. Because if the tax man isn't getting the dough from them, he's going to get it from you. And it's all apparently perfectly legal. They don't pay, you pay. To Gary B. Smith and Keith Fitz Gerald and Jonas Max Ferris on whether the IRS is going a little too far here. Gary, what do you think?

GARY B. SMITH: Not just a little, way too far. Neil, in this case, it's almost impossible for the taxpayer to fight it. One, the Social Security often doesn't even have the records detailing this overpayment, or you don't have the records because the IRS says you only have to keep your records for three years. Or you don't have the money to fight it. So it's -- I guess it is a perfect scam on behalf of the government to collect money where you have to say, well, I guess I have to pay.

CAVUTO: You know, Keith, it's one thing to take your refund back because of something you screwed up on your taxes or you owe money from prior years. I didn't even know they were allowed to do this if a relative was in this position. It's just weird to me.

KEITH FITZ-GERALD: This is a stinkbomb of the highest order, and I think it demonstrates everything that is wrong with our government at the present time. This dates, as I understand it, to a singular cause in a farm bill or something years and years ago. The fact that the government has chosen to go after these people now, I think is symptomatic of the fact that they are totally out of control. I don't like the presumptions of innocence being taken away.

CAVUTO: You know, Jonas, the argument for this is we have seen cases like this before, where you settle your parents estate, whatever is owed on that estate, has to be paid first before any funds can make their way to heirs. So how is that different than this or this from that?

JONAS MAX FERRIS: If you look at it that way, your money goes to your kids if it's under a certain amount without the government stepping in. So if you have debts, then why should those just go to the government taxpayers? In some ways, the kids should also be responsible, so you can make the case. The government is very heavy-handed, and a very (inaudible) about how they collect money. You don't want to owe the government money. You don't want to rip them off because there are laws going back to the Civil War that are very serious about them going after you.

I will say, they are finally stepping it up. You have seen this when they went after the foreigners (ph), the IRS, the Swiss bank accounts, look at all the Medicare fraud that has been going on. There's a lot of ripping off of government, all the way down to Social Security, disability, Medicare, so I like to see the government stepping it up and tightening up, but this is a very kind of ham-handed way to get at this problem.

CAVUTO: This is goose-stepping it up.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: It is weird. Judging our next president by the company they keep or the company with whom they have been keeping close ties, whether it's Condy Rice's role at Drop Box or Jeb Bush's service at Barclays Bank. Or Hillary, is that a shoe coming my way Clinton, getting 200 grand for a speech at Goldman Sachs. Should these corporate connections stick? And Gary, could they prove sticky? What do you think?

SMITH: Neil, I think this all boils down to, again, it's partisan politics. You know, the group that protested Rice with joining that board of directors at Drop Box said it's not partisan, but here are issues. No. 1, she helped start the Iraq war. Two, she helped to create Bush's torture program, and three, she served on the board of Chevron. I mean, this is -- the left out to get anyone associated with Bush, anyone associated with the Republican Party. It's just criminal.

CAVUTO: I just wonder if they make a big deal of anyone's corporate connections in the past. They are free to go wherever they want, they're free to take speech money from whoever they want, barring some dictator, I guess, it's always in the eye of the beholder, Keith. But this, to me, just seems like ancillary (ph) noise, but what do you think?

FITZ-GERALD: I think it is ridiculous. Where were they when Henry Kissinger stepped up for AmEx or (inaudible) or any of these other companies? There are lots of guys who go from Wall Street to Washington and back and forth. They either have got to come to an agreement that that kind of behavior is not a complete no-no or they need to get off their high horse.

CAVUTO: What do you make of that, Jonas?

FERRIS: I thought the whole point of being a public servant at low pay was the corporate gravy train later and all the boards and --

(CROSSTALK)

FERRIS: I'm not kidding. If you take away that gravy train, you will have bigger losers going into politics. That's one of the reasons that people take those jobs who are skilled.

(CROSSTALK)

FERRIS: This specific case, I think there is a hint of legitimacy. The Drop Box thing is more about the paranoia about the government snooping on your files, Drop Box is a file sharing on the cloud, they hoard, they literally have all your data that you put there on the cloud. So it smells bad to have anybody from the government who is involved.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: All right, I want to switch this around and talk about another development that could be very interesting maybe as this spring home shopping buying season tries to take root. Because indications are, and we have seen a lot of companies, JPMorgan Chase the latest, to say the home lending business, mortgage business, is down a lot, applications, and interest in it, off of 60 some odd percent. This shouldn't be happening this time of year. So what is going on? Should we worry? It's buffeting stocks, buffeting banks, really walloping out markets, who knows, Gary, into a correction? What do you think?

SMITH: I think we should be worried, but maybe not for the reason that you're thinking of. I think we should be worried that this is just government intrusion that has stepped all over these financial institutions. I tried to refinance about six, seven months ago, and I had to pore through so much paperwork, jump through so many hoops.

CAVUTO: You did?

SMITH: Just to refinance and pay a lower rate. If the government stepped out of the mortgage housing business, I think we'd be a lot better off.

CAVUTO: Whatever is going on here, people are just not into it. Keith, you were astute enough to point this out some months ago when the banks started laying off a lot of their mortgage personnel, that maybe that was the tipping hand here, but what's going on?

FITZ-GERALD: Well, there is a very simple explanation. No. 1, people have had it with big banks. No. 2, the government is all over them. But no. 3, more importantly, they have stepped into the retail market. Black Rock spent hundreds of millions of dollars. Groups out of California have spent hundreds of millions of dollars buying tens of thousands of homes, for the same purpose that everybody else is. They want to flip it, they want renters, everything else. So it's thrown the markets for a loop, it's brought mortgage applications down, because these guys are cash buyers, thanks to guess what, all the baiouts and all the derivatives that they sell and used to generate money on the other side of the house as collateral.

CAVUTO: You know, Jonas, I know you're in Miami, and that's a market that's been rebounding on the notion that things are back and maybe not to the giddiness they were prior to the meltdown, but certainly the lending is back, the building is back, and Miami is back, real estate is back. Maybe it's not.

FERRIS: The lending has loosened up a lot. Not all the way, there's no condo hotel on the (inaudible). But I will say, I think there is a little simpler explanation. I think the consumer backs off when the 10-year gets to about 3 percent, and rates for loans go up with it. They just don't want to -- they can't afford the house, the payments--

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: A lot of them are reporting that they are interested in getting a loan, but the banks are not giving it to them.

(CROSSTALK)

FERRIS: I think the lending is pretty loose right now. It's never going to go back to the ninja days so don't -- that is not the benchmark for how lending is supposed to be. But today lending is pretty available if you have any down payment, or if you have got equity in your house, if you have income. It's not what it was in 2005 down here, but I think the rates are low and when they go low like this week, and when you see paranoia in the market, you're going to see I think applications --

CAVUTO: I think this negativity feeds on itself. That is my worry. I don't think it's justified, but I do think it feeds on itself.

SMITH: Well, I mean, if you have an income of a million dollars a year and a credit score of 799, you have no problem getting a loan. But then you don't need one. But for most other people out there, the other fear I think is that people are still worried about the economy, they are still worried about having a job. I don't care, they probably don't want a mortgage at any rate.

CAVUTO: Something is going on. We'll keep an eye on it. Gentlemen, thank you, again. Meanwhile, what is worse? Telling a lie? Or well, spouting a number that's a lie? I've reported and you have apparently decided. All of you folks in the White House? You just might want to run for cover.

CAVUTO: And what is the deal? With a president who promised us we could keep our doctor when we couldn't and now is asking us to believe his health care enrollment numbers. But maybe we shouldn't. Paddle, stat, Washington stat credibility zero. Stat.

Eric writes there are three kinds of lies, Neil. Lies, damned lies, and these statistics. Mary Ann, President Obama lost what little credibility he had when he lied to the American people about keeping their health care. Good luck getting us to believe anything else, ever. Beverly tweets, I'm losing trust in the entire government. Waste, fraud, and abuse on both sides. You're right about that. Bryce, who in the world actually believes anything he is saying? Fewer and fewer. Tom in New Jersey, Cavuto, you're a fine one to talk about trust. You look like a used car salesman and you wear a toupee.

Tom, you are bald, aren't you?

Mark, in Cranford, New Jersey, Cavuto, if I were you, I would just out and speed up on that rocket they are building for you and leave now. This planet is lost. Get out now, but please take me with you.

Well, I'm not giving up yet, Mark, but to be safe, I am moving full speed ahead on that rocket thing. Clark in New Rochelle, I've never believed any of your numbers, but that has not stopped me from watching you. I find you funny, just like I find the president funny. You're both funny. Funny how, Clark? Funny like a clown? What do you mean by funny? Do I amuse you?

PT via Yahoo. Numbers that back up lies are just lying numbers. Profound, PT, very profound. Dexter emails, if you were a number, Cavuto, I'd give you a zero, because you're a zero. Your ethics are zero, your looks are zero, your IQ is zero. Zero, zero, zero. Yet you have emailed me before, Dexter. So that makes you a zero watching a zero, which is like zero to infinity, zero.

Jenny tweets, love Cavuto, he cracks me up, he's handsome, plus he has a sense of humor and the ability to go through these Obamacare numbers. Which by the way does take a sense of humor. Ken writes, Cavuto, you are a butthead. Ken, you are an idiot. Karen writes, Neil, interview me please. I'm older but dependable and honest. I'm going to think about that, Karen, because I'm kind of running out of options in the dependable and honest category. Pudding tweets, do you let your small children say hosed? Which means screwed? Which means, you know, I know? Watch your mouth on TV. You are a nasty hypocrite.

First of all, you go by the name Pudding, and you're giving me morality lessons? Really, Pudding?

Anyway. Frank writes, Neil, you are the shining star of Fox. If people don't watch you, they don't know what they're missing. So true. I tell this to my wife all the time. Frank, all the time. Thanks for writing, good, bad or anything in between, have a safe weekend.

urn:contentItem:5WK1-7P21-F19Y-C418-00000-00SEB, Storebrand Q2 profits fall YOY; BoE says UK banks can withstand hard Brexit2019-07-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:02ZLexisNexisExclusiveSEB, Storebrand Q2 profits fall YOY; BoE says UK banks can withstand hard BrexitMary Christine Joy

In today's Daily Dose: SEB posted a 51% year-over-year fall in second-quarter profit; Storebrand's second-quarter profit fell on a yearly basis to 451 million kroner; and the Bank of England said U.K. banks can withstand a no-deal Brexit.

* The ECB appointed Edouard Fernandez-Bollo, Kerstin af Jochnick and Elizabeth McCaul to the supervisory board of its banking supervision arm for a five-year term. Fernandez-Bollo is currently head of France's banking regulator, while af Jochnick serves as deputy governor of the Swedish central bank. McCaul is head of strategy and interim CEO of Promontory Financial Group Europe.

UK AND IRELAND

* The perceived risk of a no-deal Brexit has increased and there would be "significant volatility and asset price changes" in the event of a disorderly departure, the Bank of England said in its latest financial stability report. The central bank, however, stressed that the U.K. financial system, including banks, dealers and insurance companies, was sufficiently resilient to cope with a no-deal Brexit. Additionally, the BoE will work with the U.K. Financial Conduct Authority assess how funds' redemption terms can be better aligned with the liquidity of their assets to minimize financial stability risks.

* British financial regulators are looking into Deutsche Bank AGs latest restructuring plan. Sam Woods, head of the BoE's Prudential Regulation Authority, said the regulator is in close contact with German markets regulator BaFin and the ECB to ensure that the German lender's large-scale revamp, which entails cutting 18,000 jobs across multiple regions and businesses, are "safely executed."

* The U.K. FCA said HSBC Holdings PLC voluntarily agreed to extend a redress scheme after identifying roughly 18,500 customers in May that had not been contacted before to receive compensation for paying inappropriate debt collection fees. The lender identified the customers after expanding a review into the matter in April.

* Barclays PLC plans to shed approximately 20% of jobs at its Dubai wealth management unit, including senior positions and support staff, insiders told Bloomberg News. The bank has also reportedly offered to relocate some staff to Geneva or London.

* Ireland is set to adopt the systemic risk buffer, one of four capital buffer requirements for banks under the EU's Capital Requirements Directive IV, and give the country's central bank powers to put it into effect it in the future.

GERMANY, SWITZERLAND AND AUSTRIA

* Deutsche Bank AG CEO Christian Sewing told Handelsblatt that a "substantial number of positions" would be eliminated in Germany as part of its major overhaul. The number of redundancies resulting from the integration of Deutsche Bank and Deutsche Postbank AG had already been included in the planned 18,000 job cuts, he added. Sewing did not comment on reported estimates of some 6,000 layoffs in Germany, however. As part of its restructuring in New York, Deutsche Bank plans to lay off 126 people in the coming months, Handelsblatt noted.

* Commerzbank AG has appointed Roland Boekhout as a management board member with responsibility for its corporate clients segment, effective Jan. 1, 2020. Boekhout, currently a member of ING Groep NVs banking management board, succeeds Michael Reuther, who is leaving the German bank.

* German mobile bank N26 GmbH is launching its banking app in the U.S. as it aims to have 50 million customers around the world in the coming years.

* A severe hail storm that hit parts of Bavaria and Baden-Württemberg in southern Germany on June 10 has resulted in higher than expected costs for public insurer Versicherungskammer Bayern Versicherungsanstalt des öffentlichen Rechts, Börsen-Zeitung reported. The company said the widespread damage caused by the low pressure system will mean payouts to customers of some 80 million.

FRANCE AND BENELUX

* France's Senate passed legislation to impose a new tax on digital companies despite opposition from the U.S., Bloomberg News reported.

* The head of asset management at La Banque Postale Asset Management, Daniel Roy, unexpectedly resigned his position as chairman of the board to join another European fund manager, Les Echos reported.

* The German company Finleap, specialist in developing fintech companies, is to open an office in France in its first foreign expansion, with Nicolas Montes-Edwards serving as its manager, Les Echos noted.

SPAIN AND PORTUGAL

* Former Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria SA CEO Ángel Cano was summoned to give evidence before the Spanish High Court in an alleged spying case but he chose to exercise his right to remain silent in the judicial procedure, which also involves another former executive of the bank, Expansión wrote.

* Portugal's Novo Banco SA is set to close the sale of a 400 million real estate loan portfolio to U.S. private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, Jornal de Negócios reported. The deal, which could be completed July 12, is the latest step in the bank's efforts to remove toxic assets from its balance sheet.

ITALY AND GREECE

* Italy-based Credito Fondiario SpA is holding preliminary talks with investment firms and peers for a potential merger, insiders told Bloomberg News. The bank reportedly contacted competitors including Prelios Credit Servicing and Cerved Group SpA.

* Banca Carige SpA's advisers are working on an alternative rescue plan that foresees the creation of a good bank that would be sold to an Italian institution and a bad bank that would be managed by current shareholders without its liquidation, MF reported. A 700 million capital increase and a 200 million subordinated Tier 1 bond issue would cover the total cash call needed by Banca Carige, Il Sole 24 Ore reported, adding that only Italy's interdeposit protection fund has so far clearly expressed willingness to contribute cash.

* Italy's government could get a six-month extension to 2020 to present its plan for the sale of its 70% stake in Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA, MF reported. Options include a public tender, a series of accelerated bookbuilding or a merger with another lender. MPS, meanwhile, is selling a 350 million real estate loan portfolio, down from the initially established 600 million, Il Sole 24 Ore reported.

* U.S. investment firm BlackRock increased its stake in FinecoBank SpA to 10.233%, becoming its largest shareholder, MF reported. Il Messaggero and Reuters also covered.

* BPER Banca SpA approved to proceed with a capital increase reserved for the Sardinia Foundation that will be paid in nature through the transfer of Banco di Sardegna shares and a 150 million convertible bond, MF wrote.

* Legal & General Investment Management chose Milan as its post-Brexit foreign expansion springboard, Il Sole 24 Ore reported.

* Morgan Stanley reduced its potential stake in Credito Valtellinese SpA to 0.273% from 6.5%, Reuters wrote.

NORDIC COUNTRIES

* Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken AB reported second-quarter net profit attributable to shareholders of 4.89 billion Swedish kronor, down 51% year over year, since its year-ago results recognized special positive items from its divestment activities. First-half net profit attributable to shareholders fell 32% year over year to 9.57 billion kronor.

* Norwegian insurer Storebrand ASA reported second-quarter after-tax group profit of 451 million kroner, down from 587 million kroner a year ago.

* Norway-based Gjensidige Forsikring ASA reported second-quarter profit from continuing operations of 1.34 billion kroner, up from 841.3 million kroner a year earlier.

* Nordea Bank Abp's Swedish pension fund has moved assets worth 22 billion Swedish kronor into investments with lower carbon footprint and strict sustainability criteria during the first half, Reuters reported.

* Swedish niche bank and payment services provider Klarna is entering the mortgage market, DI Digital reported. Klarna has invested 7 million Swedish kronor in startup Borgo Bolån, which is offering mortgages in competition with traditional banks, and is also looking into offering mortgages directly.

EASTERN EUROPE

* New rules on risk weights that the Russian central bank wants to implement in 2020 are moderately credit-negative, Fitch Ratings said. Risk weights for some safer types of loans will be reduced under the new rules, which will boost regulatory capital ratios of local banks, but will also allow them to hold less capital against the same credit risk, the rating agency noted.

* Russian bad bank National Bank Trust PJSC filed a $700 million lawsuit with a London court against O1 Group owner Boris Mints and his family members over transactions that involved Otkritie Financial Corp. Bank and Rost Bank shortly before the lenders were bailed out by the central bank in 2017, news agency Prime reported.

* PAO Promsvyazbank and Russian non-state pension funds Safmar and Budushchee agreed to settle a 16.5 billion Russian ruble dispute over transactions that took place between the funds and the lender's previous owner Promsvyaz Capital BV shortly before Promsvyazbank was bailed out by the Russian central bank in December 2017, news agency RBC reported. The parties refused to disclose details of the settlement agreement as it has not yet been signed.

* The Russian State Duma plans to discuss during its July 23 session a set of legislative measures that would prohibit Russian units of international card payment systems from refusing to service cards issued by Russian banks under sanctions, Kommersant reported.

* The Polish Financial Supervision Authority lifted a requirement for BNP Paribas unit BNP Paribas Bank Polska SA to hold an additional capital buffer on its foreign currency mortgage book after the share of such loans in the lender's portfolio dropped below 10%, Rzeczpospolita reported.

* The Serbian central bank lowered its key policy rate by 25 basis points to 2.75% to provide additional support to economic growth amid low inflation. The central bank noted that inflation, which declined to an annual rate of 2.2% in May, is expected to remain in the lower part of its target tolerance band of 3% plus or minus 1.5% in 2019 and 2020.

IN OTHER PARTS OF THE WORLD

Asia-Pacific: Singapore amends delisting rules; MS Amlin to exit India; Daiwa sets up fund

Middle East & Africa: Barclays to cut jobs in Dubai; S&P acts on Israeli banks; Egypt holds rates

Latin America: Brazil pension reform passes lower house vote; IRB launches share offering

North America: Deutsche under DOJ lens over 1MDB; Powell projects dovish stance at testimony

Global Insurance: ReAssure IPO suspended; Aon cat recap; severe Louisiana weather

NOW FEATURED ON S&P GLOBAL MARKET INTELLIGENCE

Greek bank shares dip after elections as investors take profits: Shares in Greece's "big four" lenders tanked in the days following victory of the center-right New Democracy party in the July 7 general election, a trend which analysts put down to investors cashing in after a strong run of growth.

DNB holding off on share buyback ahead of new capital rules in Norway, CFO says: Norway's largest lender needs more clarity on future capital requirements before launching a buyback but DNB is confident it will be able to use this to boost shareholder payouts in future, Kjerstin Braathen said.

Europe needs to build a payments brand to avoid big tech takeover: The European payments market risks being completely taken over by U.S. and Chinese tech giants if no standardized system or European brand can be created.

Sheryl Obejera, Ed Meza, Meike Wijers, Esben Svendsen, Beata Fojcik, Yael Schrage, Brian McCulloch, Praxilla Trabattoni, and Helen Popper contributed to this report.

urn:contentItem:5N36-8N11-F03R-N02J-00000-00SEC Member Questioning Unequal Voting Rights At Snap2017-03-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:02ZLexisNexisSEC Member Questioning Unequal Voting Rights At SnapManikandan Raman

Mar 14, 2017( Benzinga: http://www.benzinga.com/news Delivered by Newstex) After its $24 billion IPO[1], Snap Inc (NYSE: SNAP[2]) now faces questions over unequal voting rights from a member of U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, according to a recent Reuters[3] report. In a unique move last week, the parent of social media app Snapchat sold $3.4 billion of shares to outside investors with no voting rights, raising concerns that those stockholders wouldn't get enough transparency or influence on matters like executive pay or strategy.

"Unequal voting rights present complex and new issues that need to be understood and addressed," Commissioner Kara Stein, a Democrat, said at a meeting of the SEC's Investor Advisory Committee in Washington. "We also must be mindful of the precedent being created." Stein said the agency should "focus on how some innovations may prove detrimental to investors." Other big tech giants have offered shares with limited voting rights to outsiders in recent years; Snap[4] was the first to offer shares to outside investors with no voting rights at all. Institutional Investment Take Reuters noted the topic of unequal voting rights comes at a time when three of the five commission seats at SEC are currently empty and the sole member other than Stein, Republican Michael Piwowar, is its acting chairman. President Donald Trump has nominated Wall Street attorney Jay Clayton, also a Republican, as the U.S. securities regulator's permanent head. His confirmation would put Stein in the minority and possibly limit her influence. Meanwhile, Ken Bertsch, executive director of the Council of Institutional Investors, which represents large pension funds and other asset managers, said share structures like Snap's pose risks such as leaving founders in control decades after their prime. "At some point," Reuters said quoting Bertsch, "there's some question of market confusion and a disabling of passive strategies." urn:contentItem:5XKP-0S81-DYRJ-04F4-00000-00Second Time Could Be Charm for Washington State Privacy Bill2019-11-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:23:02ZLexisNexisTOP NEWSSecond Time Could Be Charm for Washington State Privacy Bill

Washington state is closer to privacy consensus for the 2020 legislative session, said Senate Environment, Energy and Technology Committee Chairman Reuven Carlyle (D) in an interview. After months of talks, industry and consumer privacy groups see momentum on a bill that failed in 2019. The privacy groups said a draft last week improves upon the previous version they thought weighed too heavily in industry's favor.

Up against the buzzer last spring, the House didn't take up a Senate-passed version that Microsoft and other tech companies backed but privacy groups condemned (see 1904180036). Carlyle sees "a desire to get to yes" and aims to gain consensus more quickly this time: "I do not expect this to go to the last day." Carlyle spoke to new House Speaker Laurie Jinkins (D), who he said is "very committed to resolution" and more up on tech issues than the previous speaker. Releasing a draft two months before session starts allows time for feedback, Carlyle said this week.

Carlyle said he has listened "very intently to the deep concerns of some of the opponents" and is working closely with House Innovation, Technology and Economic Development Committee Chairman Zack Hudgins (D). Carlyle tried to make consumer rights more explicit and took another pass at consent, enforcement and various definitions, he said. Consumer groups had a "very legitimate" concern about a loophole allowing companies to continue using data even after a user requested its deletion, Carlyle said. He didn't add a private right of action sought by some privacy groups but would be open to reviewing that issue in a few years.

Washington's privacy bill is "incredibly important to get right," said Center for Democracy and Technology Privacy and Data Project Director Michelle Richardson in an interview. "Everybody's watching Washington as one of the most likely to get across the line" in 2020 because lawmakers "got so far last year." Businesses seek an alternative to the California Consumer Privacy Act to use as a model elsewhere, while consumer privacy groups see "potential to add in new protections for users that we haven't seen in other states," including data minimization and secondary-use limitations, she said.

Privacy advocates complained last session about feeling excluded from the process in favor of Washington-based tech companies like Amazon and Microsoft. "It's been a very open process," Carlyle said about the fresh effort to reach consensus, though he said process concerns are sometimes "euphemisms for the outcome." Carlyle sees the presence of big tech companies in his state as an advantage for writing a good privacy bill.

Hudgins appreciates Carlyle "listening to my concerns with such intentionality, and the clear changes he made to many parts of his bill," the House member emailed in an update last week with the new draft. "I do have some concerns and questions and I am working through those details."

Positive Steps

The new draft would explicitly give consumers rights to opt out, as well as to access, correct, delete and move data.

It would require businesses to conduct a data protection assessment for personal data processing activities "that present a heightened risk of harm to consumers, such as processing for purposes of targeted advertising or processing sensitive data," said a summary. The state attorney general would enforce the proposed law, which has no private right of action. Proposed privacy rules apply to businesses that target residents and that control or process data of more than 100,000 consumers or derive 50 percent of gross revenue from sale of personal information and control or process data of more than 25,000 consumers.

Washington's bill is "moving in the right direction" but isn't "there yet," said CDT's Richardson. It has "more principles that are about better corporate behavior and not just individual responsibilities," she said. But CDT is worried the bill is more concerned with whether a company tells consumers what it's going to do than making objective standards about what a company should be doing. The group supports a method for citizen complaints to supplement limited AG resources, though including a private right of action wouldn't likely be a "red line" for the group, Richardson said.

The measure is improved from last session, emailed Justin Brookman, Consumer Reports director-consumer privacy and technology policy. "There's been more outreach than there was at this point last year," showing "the extent of opposition from advocates last year may have surprised them." Brookman applauded removal of language "predicating privacy rights on companies' internal risk determinations." He said lawmakers should tighten definitions including for sale, de-identified and pseudonymous, and add more consumer protections about first-party obligations and nondiscrimination.

The draft bill improves in some ways on the California Consumer Privacy Act and EU's general data protection regulation, said Interactive Advertising Bureau Senior Director-Public Policy Alex Propes in a statement: "We welcome the acknowledgement of the benefits of pseudonymized data in providing meaningful protections to consumers." IAB supports opt-out here over opt-in in GDPR, he said. Differences with state laws in California and Nevada show "the need for Congress to pass a uniform federal privacy standard that provides greater clarity to consumers and businesses alike," he said.

TechNet and members are reviewing the draft and conversing with legislators, said Samantha Kersul, TechNet executive director-Washington. Microsoft, Comcast and others in industry didn't comment through Thursday.

The Bitfinex/Tether saga is insane and only just getting started. If crypto is going to be adopted, we need to have more trust in our trading venues. That requires close supervision of trading venues and markets.' Ari David Paul, the founder of BlockTower Capital, was also featured in the altcoin news[4] for reacting to the post and stating: 'Hopefully we're not headed toward a world where voluntary commerce can be stamped out globally. So for a global asset, this will always be an issue. Fortunately, you don't need to care. $1b in CME future volume is real and traceable. Manipulation is temporary by nature.'
